Description: Floor and ring foot sherd of East Greek pottery cup or bowl, possibly a South Ionian cup with everted rim; glaze fired orange; interior glazed; exterior: trace of reserved band above glazed band at bottom of wall; foot and underside reserved save for ring at centre; inscription on underside.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the ring foot possibly finds parallels with his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 10. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The place of production of the vase was determined as probably Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.1025) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXIII, no. 357)
Johnston 2006a / Trademarks on Greek Vases: Addenda (East Greek 189)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.245) (Phase 3)
